segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
5. Sabbath
45. With Bojjhā on the Sabbath

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho bojjhā upāsikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho bojjhaṃ upāsikaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the laywoman Bojjhā went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:

segments.pli: “Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato, bojjhe, uposatho upavuttho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
segments.en: “Bojjhā, the observance of the sabbath with its eight factors is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.

segments.pli: Kathaṃ upavuttho ca, bojjhe, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro?
segments.en: And how should it be observed?
It’s when a noble disciple reflects:

segments.pli: ‘yāvajīvaṃ arahanto pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā nihitadaṇḍā nihitasatthā lajjī dayāpannā sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampino viharanti.
segments.en: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.

segments.pli: Ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharāmi.
segments.en: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.

segments.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
segments.en: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

segments.pli: Iminā paṭhamena aṅgena samannāgato hoti … pe ….
segments.en: This is its first factor. …

segments.pli: ‘Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭiviratā nīcaseyyaṃ kappenti—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
segments.en: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.

segments.pli: Ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato nīcaseyyaṃ kappemi—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
segments.en: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.

segments.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
segments.en: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
This is its eighth factor.

segments.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, bojjhe, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
segments.en: The observance of the sabbath with its eight factors in this way is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.
How much so?

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bojjhe, yo imesaṃ soḷasannaṃ mahājanapadānaṃ pahūtarattaratanānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreyya, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: Suppose you were to rule as sovereign lord over these sixteen great countries—Aṅga, Magadha, Kāsī, Kosala, Vajjī, Malla, Ceti, Vaṅga, Kuru, Pañcāla, Maccha, Sūrusena, Assaka, Avanti, Gandhāra, and Kamboja—full of the seven kinds of precious things.

segments.pli: aṅgānaṃ magadhānaṃ kāsīnaṃ kosalānaṃ vajjīnaṃ mallānaṃ cetīnaṃ vaṅgānaṃ kurūnaṃ pañcālānaṃ macchānaṃ sūrasenānaṃ assakānaṃ avantīnaṃ gandhārānaṃ kambojānaṃ, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatassa uposathassa etaṃ kalaṃ nāgghati soḷasiṃ.
segments.en: This wouldn’t be worth a sixteenth part of the sabbath with its eight factors.
Why is that?

segments.pli: Kapaṇaṃ, bojjhe, mānusakaṃ rajjaṃ dibbaṃ sukhaṃ upanidhāya.
segments.en: Because human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.

segments.pli: Yāni, bojjhe, mānusakāni paññāsa vassāni, cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
segments.en: Fifty years in the human realm is one day and night for the Gods of the Four Great Kings.
Thirty such days make up a month.
Twelve such months make up a year.

segments.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni pañca vassasatāni cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
segments.en: The life span of the Gods of the Four Great Kings is five hundred of these divine years.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
segments.en: It’s possible that a woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the Gods of the Four Great Kings.

segments.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
segments.en: This is what I was referring to when I said:
‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’
A hundred years in the human realm …

segments.pli: tāni, bojjhe, mānusakāni dve vassasatāni … pe …
segments.en: Two hundred years in the human realm …
Four hundred years in the human realm …
Eight hundred years in the human realm …

segments.pli: soḷasa vassasatāni paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
segments.en: Sixteen hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others.
Thirty such days make up a month.
Twelve such months make up a year.

segments.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni soḷasa vassasahassāni paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
segments.en: The life span of the gods who control the creations of others is sixteen thousand of these divine years.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
segments.en: It’s possible that a woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others.

segments.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
segments.en: This is what I was referring to when I said:
‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’
You shouldn’t kill living creatures, or steal,

segments.pli: Musā na bhāse na ca majjapo siyā;
segments.en: or lie, or drink alcohol.
Be celibate, refraining from sex,
and don’t eat at night, the wrong time.

segments.pli: Mālaṃ na dhāre na ca gandhamācare,
segments.en: Not wearing garlands or applying perfumes,
you should sleep on a low bed, or a mat on the ground.
This is the eight-factored sabbath, they say,
explained by the Buddha, who has gone to suffering’s end.

segments.pli: Cando ca suriyo ca ubho sudassanā,
segments.en: The moon and sun are both fair to see,
radiating as far as they revolve.
Those shining ones in the sky light up the quarters,
dispelling the darkness as they traverse the heavens.
All of the wealth that’s found in this realm—
pearls, gems, fine beryl too,
horn-gold or mountain gold,
or natural gold dug up by marmots—
they’re not worth a sixteenth part
of the mind developed with love,
as all the constellations of stars can’t equal the light of the moon.

segments.pli: Tasmā hi nārī ca naro ca sīlavā,
segments.en: So an ethical woman or man,
who has observed the eight-factored sabbath,
having made merit whose outcome is happiness,
blameless, they go to a heavenly place.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī…

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Bojjhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Bojjhā exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.
